questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with a 3 cm breast lump in the upper medial quadrant . The lump has an uneven, bosselated surface , and the overlying skin is mildly ulcerated . Microscopic examination reveals the given findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Age Group

30-50 years

Growth

Rapid, large lobulated mass

Surface

Uneven, bosselated

Histology

Stromal overgrowth, leaf-like pattern

Treatment

Wide local excision / mastectomy

questions.text: Which patient has better prognosis in breast cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Luminal A

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a lesion over his left ear. It slowly grew in size over the past 3 months, and he is a chronic smoker with 20 pack years. Vitals are within normal limits, and his physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. The histopathologic evaluation shows keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma

Definition

It is a type of skin cancer that arises from the squamous cells, which are the flat cells found in the epidermis, mucous membranes & tissues lining your organs. It is the second most common type of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma.

Risk factors
  • High sunlight exposure
  • Arsenic exposure.
  • Immunosuppression (organ transplant, HIV)
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Human papilloma virus.

Presentation

It commonly presents as papules, nodules, or plaques with induration and signs of photodamage like crusting and scaling.

Diagnosis

It involves physical examination and biopsy

Histopathology

Reveals characteristic keratin pearls.

Treatment
  • Primary treatment involves wide surgical excision with margins.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) aids in intraoperative histopathological examination.
  • Advanced cases may require radiation or chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on her face that was growing rapidly in size and associated with itching. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Malignant melanoma

Definition

Melanoma is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it is a rare skin cancer, it has a high mortality rate. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds.

Risk factors
  • Positive family history.
  • Fair skin.
  • Genetics: CDKN2A (chromosome 9p21), MC1R, and TYR genes.
  • Nevus:
    • Congenital melanocytic nevi.
    • Junctional nevi.
    • Atypical nevi.
    • Dysplastic nevi.

Diagnostic criteria

(Pneumonic: ABCDE)

  • Asymmetry: Irregular shapes.
  • Border: Irregular.
  • Colour: Various colours present or uneven distribution.
  • Diameter: > 6 mm.
  • Evolution: Changes in lesion over time (size, shape, itching, or bleeding)

Investigations
  • Clinical examination.
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

Management
  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.

questions.text: Most common primary source of metastasis to the brain is:

A factory worker working in a plastic pipe factory presented to the OPD with weight loss and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for 6 months duration. He had hepatomegaly. Further investigation revealed that most of the liver was replaced by a hemorrhagic tumour with extensive necrosis. What can be the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Hepatic Angiosarcoma

Definition
  • It is a high-grade vascular malignancy that arises from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels or lymphatic channels.
  • It is the most common sarcoma arising in the liver, especially in those with significant exposure to Vinyl chloride.

Common in

Men and elderly

Risk Factors
  • Arsenic,
  • Radiation,
  • Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast)

Metastasis
  • It can spread through lymphatic and hematogenous routes, but due to the tumour's vascular nature, hematogenous spread (via blood vessels) is more common.
  • The liver and lungs are common sites of metastasis, reflecting the tumour's aggressive nature

Clinical presentation

It presents as a red-brown, indurated, and ulcerated skin lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumour in the retroperitoneal space?
What is the most likely primary site of origin for metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK 7 (-), CK 20 (+), and CDX-1 (+) IHC markers?
questions.explanation:
CK7

CK20

CDX1

Colon cancer

(-) ve

(+) ve

(+) ve

Breast cancer (Option B ruled out)

(+) ve

(-) ve

(-) ve

Pancreatic cancer (Option C ruled out)

(+) ve

(+) ve

(-) ve

Ovarian cancer (Option D ruled out)

(+) ve

(-) ve

(-) ve

questions.text: Match the following: A. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of foot measuring 3cm x 2cm 1. Excision biopsy B. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck 2. Core needle biopsy C. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh 3. USG guided FNAC D. Solitary thyroid nodule 4. Wedge biopsy
questions.explanation:
Condition

Investigations

Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of foot measuring 3cm x 2cm

Wedge biopsy (removing a small wedge-shaped tissue sample from the nodule) is commonly performed on a Marjolin ulcer (a malignant transformation in a chronic non-healing wound).

1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck

Excision biopsy is commonly used to evaluate a lymph node.

Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh

Core needle biopsy involves obtaining a small cylindrical core of tissue from the lymph node for pathological examination.

Solitary thyroid nodule

USG guided FNAC is used to evaluate a solitary thyroid nodule by guiding a needle into the tumour to collect cells for cytological analysis.

questions.text: What is the meaning of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in the context of a 54-year-old woman diagnosed with stage 2A cervical cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemotherapy is given along with radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumour.

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases.

questions.correct_answer: C. Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumour.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of HTN came in with complaints of headaches for five days. All classical signs, increased metanephrine levels, and other investigations indicate pheochromocytoma. What is the best imaging modality for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - MIBG

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with redness and a Peau d'orange appearance involving more than 2/3 of her breast, without any palpable lump in the breast. On further evaluation, it is found that the skin involvement extends to the chest wall and is suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma . What is the appropriate TNM staging for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct option D - T4d

T Category T Criteria
TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1a Tumor size ≤1 mm
T1b Tumor size >1 mm but ≤5 mm
T1c Tumor size >5 mm but ≤10 mm
T1d Tumor size >10 mm but ≤20 mm
T2 Tumor size >20 mm but ≤50 mm
T3 Tumor size >50mm
T4a Tumor with chest wall invasion
T4b Tumor with macroscopic skin changes including ulceration and/or satellite skin nodules and/or edema
T4c Tumor with criteria of both T4a and T4b
T4d Inflammatory carcinoma

T Category T Criteria
TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1a Tumor size ≤1 mm
T1b Tumor size >1 mm but ≤5 mm
T1c Tumor size >5 mm but ≤10 mm
T1d Tumor size >10 mm but ≤20 mm
T2 Tumor size >20 mm but ≤50 mm
T3 Tumor size >50mm
T4a Tumor with chest wall invasion
T4b Tumor with macroscopic skin changes including ulceration and/or satellite skin nodules and/or edema
T4c Tumor with criteria of both T4a and T4b
T4d Inflammatory carcinoma

questions.text: A female presents with a non-palpable lump in the breast. The biopsy and IHC results reveal Luminal A. What characteristics are included under Luminal A?

options.label: A
options.text: ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu positive

options.label: B
options.text: ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with low proliferation

options.label: C
options.text: ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with high proliferation

questions.correct_answer: B. ER positive, PR positive, Her2 neu negative with low proliferation
questions.explanation:
Subtype

ER Status

PR Status

HER2 Status

Ki-67 Status

Characteristics

Luminal A

+

+

-

Low

Generally, it is low grade, has a better prognosis, and is responsive to hormonal therapy.

Luminal B

+

+ or -

+ or -

High

Higher grade, poor prognosis compared to Luminal A, may require targeted HER2 therapy following status.

HER2-enriched

-

-

+

High

Aggressive, higher grade, poor prognosis, requires targeted HER2 therapy.

Basal-like

-

-

-

High

Includes triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), highly aggressive, no targeted hormonal therapy.

Claudin-low

-

-

+ or -

Often High

Often associated with poor prognosis and aggressive behaviour, typically lacks response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: In a follow-up case of prostate cancer, what do we need to check?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Significance in Prostate Cancer Follow-Up

PSA (Prostate-Specific Antigen)

Most important marker; rising levels indicate recurrence or metastasis

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Marker for bone metastases, but not routinely used for follow-up

Acid Phosphatase (PAP)

Older marker, now largely replaced by PSA

Testosterone

Checked in hormone-sensitive cases on ADT to confirm castrate levels

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra is via?
questions.explanation:
Route

Mechanism & Common Sites

Local spread

Direct extension into the seminal vesicles, bladder, or rectum

Lymphatic spread

Obturator, internal & external iliac nodes are commonly involved

Hematogenous spread

Via Batson’s venous plexus → lumbar vertebrae, pelvis, femur, ribs

Arterial spread

Rare, usually occurs late in disease progression

questions.text: What is the T stage for this tumour in the oral cavity?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Oral Cavity Cancer (AJCC 8th Edition):

T (Primary Tumor):

Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed.

Tis

Carcinoma in situ.

T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, ≤5 mm depth of invasion (DOI).

T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm DOI. (Option A ruled out)

T4a

Moderately advanced local disease - Invades through cortical bone, deep/ extrinsic muscle of tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face.

T4b

Very advanced local disease - Invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base, or encases internal carotid artery. (Option D ruled out)

N (Regional Lymph Nodes):

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤3 cm in greatest dimension.

N2
  • N2a: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral node, >3 cm but ≤6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • N2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm).
  • N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, all ≤6 cm.

N3
  • N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm in greatest dimension, ENE(-).
  • N3b: Metastasis in any node(s) with clinically overt ENE(+).

M (Distant Metastasis):

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

Stage Grouping of oral cancer

Stage 0

Tis N0 M0

Stage I

T1 N0 M0

Stage II

T2 N0 M0

Stage III

T3 N0 M0 or T1-3 N1 M0

Stage IVA

T4a N0-1 M0 or T1-4a N2 M0

Stage IVB

Any T N3 M0 or T4b Any N M0

Stage IVC

Any T Any N M1

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred for lowering uric acid to prevent renal damage in tumor lysis syndrome ?
What category of malignancy do rodent ulcers belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - B

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is the most common primary for brain metastasis ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Lung

questions.text: Which is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Hypophosph

questions.text: Cock's peculiar tumor is:
questions.correct_answer: B. Infected sebaceous cyst of scalp
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Infected sebaceous cyst of scalp: 

Cock’s peculiar tumor

  • Infected sebaceous cyst of scalp

Pott’s puffy tumor

  • Osteomyelitis of skull bones
  • MC skull bone involved – Frontal bone
